summary.p: This heavily annotated manuscript of the Amarakośa, the well-known Sanskrit lexicon, was part of the collection of J. M. F. Guérin. It has been bound along with two other works from the collection.
The manuscript seems to contain two parts: U1, a single-folio fragment, and U2, which is a complete manuscript in 90 folios.

U1 is unnumbered, but it is clearly the first folio of a manuscript. It contains the beginning of the Amarakośa on the recto side, and a commentary on the verso side (although this folio was probably bound backwards).

The next folio, numbered 1, marks the beginning of U2. It contains the beginning of the text again starting on the verso side, in a different hand, with a marginal commentary. A third commentary in red ink runs from the end of U1 to the beginning of U2.
A colophon at the end, which seems to have been erased and rewritten, gives the name of the scribe of U2, Govarddhana, and the date, equivalent to 1684 CE.

handNote.desc: The name of the scribe is Govarddhana.
Scribe of the commentary that runs across both U1 and the beginning of U2, in red ink.

additions.desc: JG stamp (for J. Guérin), beginning and end.

binding.p: Bound as a book along with two other manuscripts.

origin.origDate: There seem to be two dates at the end of U2. The second one gives a śāka date of aṅgākāśarasendu, or 1606, in the month of jyaiṣṭha, corresponding to 1684 CE. If this is the date of the completion of U2, then the whole bundle, including U1, would have been put together some time later.
